newsitem.title: FRENCH GUIANA: Satellite problems delay Ariane rocket launch.
newsitem.headline: Satellite problems delay Ariane rocket launch.

text.p: The launch of Western Europe's 93rd Ariane rocket, due to carry a U.S. communications satellite, has been postponed by at least three months, space officials said on Wednesday.

They said technical problems will delay the launch of satellite PANAMSAT-6 for operator PANAMASAT based in Greenwich, Connecticut, which was originally scheduled for mid-December from Kourou in French Guiana.

The company will substitute another satellite payload for a launch programmed for late January. Experts said the new payload would be telecommuncations satellites for Argentina and U.S. company GTE Corp

"A technical incident on the PANAMSAT-6 satellite means a three-month delay at least. This leads us to prepare for the next client in line," Roger Solari, head of operations at the Arianespace company in French Guiana, told local radio.
Solari gave no details of the technical problem.
A total of 10 Ariane-4 rockets were successfully launched in 1996 from the European Space Agency (ESA) launch centre in Kourou, French Guiana on the northeast coast of South America.
The first of a new generation of Ariane-5 rockets exploded on its maiden launch on June 4.
The Paris-based Arianespace company said it has firm orders to launch 40 heavy satellites worth $3.4 billion.
